title: Chris McNally’s Falconer Cycles Pro Cruiser Homage: A Palette Bike – John Watson
content:
Cameron Falconer is well-versed in the world of vintage cruisers and klunkers. We featured his Pro Cruiser in 2020, along with other custom bikes inspired by models from the late 1970s. Today, we’ve got a special 27.5+ Pro Cruiser, 3-bar homage Falconer, hand-painted by San Francisco artist Chris McNally…

3-Bar Frame Homage

Eagle-eyed fans of the late 1970s production bikes and early mountain bikes will pick up on the creative easter eggs and breadcrumbs Cameron Falconer placed in Chris McNally’s single-speed MTB. For starters, the fork is inspired by the first production mountain bike product, the Cook Brothers Racing fork, designed by Don Koski.

Then there’s the Lawwill-Knight-inspired diagatube that pierces the downtube and is actually welded to the head tube. It’s also welded to the seat tube and down tube. This technique was used in the Pro Cruiser but originated as a design detail by Terry Knight, used in the Champion BMX frames.

Cameron Falconer’s 1979 Pro Cruiser by California Travis

The original Pro Cruiser was prototyped by Don Koski in 1978, immediately ramping up the Lawwill-Knight brand’s first batch in the summer of 1978. Six hundred frames in total were produced.

The rear end is a classic loop tail design, calling back to early BMX bikes, the Cook Brothers Racing Cruiser, and the 1980s Yeti FRO. Unlike Travis’ Krusty Diamond, which featured an eccentric bottom bracket and an axle interrupting the loop, Chris’ bike uses plate track ends for chain tension and stays true to the looptail aesthetic.

Chris and Color

Chris McNally’s watercolor illustrations are synonymous with the spirit of exploration and the stoke of the outdoors. We first met over a decade ago and have done a number of bike tours together. His illustration work elevates his client’s cachet and his natural landscapes are vignettes into an ephemeral glimpse of bike tours past.

What I like about Chris’ artwork is his eye for color. And one day while hanging out with him in his shop, I got sucked into these color wash sheets. These abstract paintings capture various tones and hues, working harmoniously together, creating a subtle and calm balance. From cools to warm palettes, these experimental exercises flex Chris’ uncanny eye for color.

Furthermore, his palettes showcase his process. When I look at Chris’ work, I can immediately smell the landscapes – many of which are recognizable just based on the color palette alone. While he might be most famous for his Marin County rolling green hills, I really love his Baja series.

After geeking out about his work, I peeked into his bike closet and saw his Falconer. Immediately, the bike presented a reflection of Chris’ eye for color.

Handmade Finishing

I asked Chris how he achieved this look. He remarked that it was a base beige powder coat in “the most boring color ever,” as Cameron replied to Chris’ request. Wanting to experiment with a handmade finish, he then made stencils and used Spray.Bike‘s bike paint, colored pencils, paint pens, and even Xerox transfers on top. The Falconer logo is the latter. Chris remarked that the Xerox transfer actually dissolved some of the paint!

The end product, when paired with the silver components and purple bits, is nothing short of a rideable piece of art.

My mind immediately was drawn back to Chris’ color wash test sheets, particularly the two highlighted here. I returned a few days later with my bike portrait setup, took photos of these two sheets, and then pedaled the bike off to find a neutral-colored wall.

Overlaying the color sheets, I shot a series of double exposures until I found a composition I felt complemented Chris’ handiwork. Not wanting to overdo the effect, I still documented the bike in detail, noting all of Chris’ Easter eggs. I particularly loved the banana slugs, poison oak (my skin itches just looking at it!) and note to Cameron Falconer on the non-drive chainstay: Sorry, Cam!

I once read an interview with French filmmaker François Truffaut, who believed that once painted art is recorded by a camera, it loses its soul and impact. He believed that art can only be truly experienced in person. If I recall correctly, it was a critique of Alfred Hitchcock’s film Spellbound, which features set design by Salvador Dali.

Truffaut was from a different era, and while he predicted what films of the future would hold, I doubt he realized the ease of video or photography in our world. I acknowledge that cameras struggle to render some colors and that Chris’ test sheets contain whole worlds across the color spectrum. It’s also hard to capture the beauty of Chris’ work or the presence this bike has in person. But as someone who doesn’t really view my own work wholly as art, this documentation and experimentation made me feel a sense of artistic fulfillment.

As I rode the bike back to Chris’ studio, eager to show him the in-camera double exposure, I thought about that Truffaut quote from my college film studies classes. Rolling into the studio, I greeted Chris with the camera screen preview.

“Oh man! That reminds me of this project from last year,” Chris said as he opened a file on the screen that very much captured the intent of this whole exercise. In the Chris McNally studio, the wonders never cease to amaze.
